sourceDesc.p: LION text of Wing B1581 (1647), the Beaumont and Fletcher folio, checked against EEBO images from that text.

Play details
The humorous lieutenant. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1647. Date first performed: 1619-1625?

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. King Antigonus The Humorous Lieutenant Celia Demetrius Embassador1 Embassador2 Embassador3 Seleucus Lysimachs Ptolomie Leucippe Leontius Timon Charinthus Menippus 1Gent. 2Gent. Maid1 Citizen1 Citizen2 Usher1 Usher2 Maid2 combined voices old woman Phebe Prologue and Epilogue Soldier Lord Governess Lady Phisitian1 Phisitian2 Herald Host. Magician Magician's song Answer to song

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: 1.Usher.
sp.l: Round round, perfume it round, quick, look ye
Diligently the state be right, are these the richest
Cushions? Fie, fie, who waits in the wardrobe?

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: But pray tell me, do you think for certain
These Ambassadors shall have this morning audience?

sp.speaker: 1.Ush.
sp.l: They shall have it: Lord that you live at Court
And understand not? I tell you they must have it.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: Upon what necessity?

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Still you are of the trick of Court, sell your place

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: And sow your grounds, you are not for this tillage.
Madams, the best way is the upper lodgings,
There you may see at ease.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: We thank you sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Would you have all these slighted? who should report then
The Ambassadors were handsome men? his beard
A neat one? the fire of his eyes quicker than lightning,
And when it breaks, as blasting? his legs, though little ones,
Yet movers of a mass of understanding?
Who shall commend their clothes: who shall take notice
Of the most wise behaviour of their feathers?
Ye live a raw man here.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: I think I do so.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Why, whether would you all press?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: Usher Good Master

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: My wife, and some few of my honest neighbours, here.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Prithee begone thou and thy honest neighbours,
Thou lookest like an ass, why, whether would you fish face

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: If I might have
But the honour to see you at my poor house sir,
A Capon bridled, and saddled I will assure your worship,
A shoulder of mutton, and a pottle of wine sir;
I know your brother, he was as like ye,
And shot the best at buts --

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: A -- upon thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Some music I will assure you too,
My toy sir, can play of the virginals.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Prithee good toy,
Take away thy shoulder of mutton, it is fly blown,
And shoulder take thy flap along, here is no place for ye;
Nay then you had best be knocked.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would fain see him
The glory of this place, makes me remember,
But die those thoughts, die all but my desires,
Even those to death are sick too; he is not here,
Nor how my eyes may guide me --

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: What is your business?
Who keeps the outward door there? here is fine shuffling,
You waistcoater you must go back.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is not,
There cannot be, six days and never see me?
There must not be desire; sir do you think
That if you had a Mistress --

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Death, she is mad.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And were your self an honest man? it cannot --

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: What a devil hast thou to do with me or my honesty?
Will you be jogging, good nimble tongue,
My fellow door keeper.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: Prithee let her alone.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: The King is coming,
And shall we have an agent from the suburbs
Come to crave audience too?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Before I thought ye
To have a little breeding, some tang of Gentry;
But now I take ye plainly,
Without the help of any perspective,
For that ye cannot alter.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: An ass sir, you bray as like one,
And by my troth, methinks as ye stand now,
Considering who to kick next, you appear to me
Just with that kind of gravity, and wisdom;
Your place may bear the name of Gentleman,
But if ever any of that butter stick to your bread --

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: You must be modester.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Let him use me nobler,
And wear good clothes to do good offices;
They hang upon a fellow of his virtue,
As though they hung on Gibbets.

sp.speaker: 2.Ush.
sp.l: A perilous wench.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Thrust her into a corner, I will no more on her.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: You have enough, go pretty maid, stand close,
And use that little tongue, with a little more temper.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I thank ye sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: When the shows are past,
I will have ye into the cellar, there we will dine
A very pretty wench, a witty rogue,
And there we will be as merry, can ye be merry?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: O very merry.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: Only ourselves ; this churlish fellow shall not know.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: And can you love a little?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Love exceedingly:
I have cause to love you dear sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: Then I will carry ye,
And show you all the pictures, and the hangings,
The lodgings, gardens, and the walks: and then (sweet)
You shall tell me where you lie.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes marry will I.

sp.speaker: 2.Ush.
sp.l: And it shall go hard but I will send ye a venison pasty,
And bring a bottle of wine along.

sp.speaker: 1.Ush.
sp.l: Make room there.

sp.speaker: 2.Ush.
sp.l: Room there afore, stand close, the train is coming

body.stage: Enter King, Antigonous, Tymon, Charinthus, Menippus.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Have I yet left a beauty to Catch fools?
Yet, yet, I see him not, O what a misery
Is love, expected long, deluded longer!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Conduct in the Ambassadors.

sp.speaker: 1.Ush.
sp.l: Make room there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They shall not wait long answer --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yet he comes not.
Why are eyes set on these, and multitudes
Follow to make these wonders? O good gods!
What would these look like if my love were here?
But I am fond, forgetful.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now your grievance,
Speak short, and have as short dispatch.

sp.speaker: 1.Em.
sp.l: Then thus sir:
In all our Royal Masters names, We tell you
Ye have done injustice, broke the bonds of concord,
And from their equal shares, from Alexander
Parted, and so possessed, not like a brother,
But as an open Enemy, Ye have hedged in
Whole Provinces, manned and maintained these injuries;
And daily with your sword (though they still honour ye)
Make bloody roads, take Towns, and ruin Castles,
And still their sufferance feels the weight.

sp.speaker: 2.Em.
sp.l: Think of that love great sir, that honoured friendship
Yourself hold with our Masters, think of that strength
When you were all one body, all one mind;
When all your swords struck one way, when your angers,
Like so many brother billows rose together,
And curling up your foaming crests, defied
Even mighty Kings, and in their falls, entombed them;
O think of these; and you that have been Conquerors,
That ever led your fortunes open eyed,
Chained fast by confidence; you that fame courted,
Now ye want enemies and men to match ye;
Let not your own swords seek your ends to shame ye.

body.stage: Enter Demetrius with a Javelin, and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 3 Emb.
sp.l: Choose which you will, or peace or war,
We come prepared for either.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Room for the Prince there.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: was it the Prince they said? how my heart trembled!
It is he indeed; what a sweet noble fierceness
Dwells in his eyes? young Meleager like,
When he returned from slaughter of the Boar,
Crowned with the loves and honours of the people,
With all the gallant youth of Greece, he looks now,
Who could deny him love?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Hail Royal Father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ye are welcome from your sport sir, do you see this gent.,
You that bring thunders in your mouths, and earthquakes
To shake and totter my designs? can you imagine
(You men of poor and common apprehensions)
Whilst I admit this man, my son, this nature
That in one look carries more fire, and fierceness,
Than all your masters in their lives: dare I admit him,
Admit him thus, even to my side, My bosom,
When he is fit to rule, when all men cry him,
And all hopes hang about his head; thus place him,
His weapon hatched in blood, all these attending
When he shall make their fortunes, all as sudden
In any expedition he shall point them,
As arrows from a Tartars bow, and speeding,
Dare I do this, and fear an enemy?
Fear your great Master? yours? or yours?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: O Hercules
Who says you do sir? Is there anything
In these men's faces, or their Masters actions,
Able to work such wonders?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now he speaks:
O I could dwell upon that tongue forever .

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You call them Kings, they never wore those royalties
Nor in the progress of their lives arrived yet
At any thought of King: imperial dignities,
And powerful god-like actions, fit for Princes
They can no more put on,and make them sit right,
Than I can with this mortal hand hold heaven:
Poor petty men, nor have I yet forgot
The chiefest honours time, and merit gave them:
Lysimachus your Master, at his best,
His highest, and his hopefullest dignities
Was but grand-master of the Elephants;
Seleucus of the Treasure; and for Ptolomy,
A thing not thought on then, scarce heard of yet,
Some master of ammunition: and must these men --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What a brave confidence flows from his spirit?
O sweet young man!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Must these hold pace with us,
And on the same field hang their memories?
Must these examine what the wills of Kings are?
Prescribe to their designs, and chain their actions
To their restraints? be friends, and foes when they please?
Send out their thunders, and their menaces,
As if the fate of mortal thing were theirs?
Go home good men, and tell your masters from us,
We do them too much honour to force from them
Their barren countries, ruin their vast Cities,
And tell them out of love, we mean to leave them
(Since they will needs be Kings) no more to tread on,
Than they have able wits, and powers to manage,
And so we shall befriend them: ha? what does she there?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: This is your answer King.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is like to prove so.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fie sweet, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray ye do not chide me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You do yourself much wrong, and me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pray you pardon me,
I feele my fault, which only was committed
Through my dear love to you: I have not seen ye,
And how can I live then? I have not spoke to ye --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know this week ye have not; I will redeem all.
You are so tender now: think where you are, sweet.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What other light have I left?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee Celia,
Indeed, I will see ye presently.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done sir:
You will not miss?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: By this, and this, I will not.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is in your will: and I must be obedient.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: no more of these assemblies.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am commanded.

sp.speaker: 1 Ush.
sp.l: Room for the Lady there: Madam, my service --

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: My Coach if it please you Lady.

sp.speaker: 2 Ush.
sp.l: Room before there.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: The honour Madam, but to wait upon you --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My servants, and my state:
Lord, how they flock now?
Before I was afraid they would have beat me;
How these flies play in the Sunshine? pray ye no services,
Or if ye needs must play the hobby horses,
Seek out some beauty that affects them: farewell,
Nay pray ye spare: Gentlemen I am old enough
To go alone at these years, without crutches.

sp.speaker: 2.Ush.
sp.l: Well , I could curse now: but that will not help me,
I made as sure account of this wench now, immediately,
Do but consider how the devil has crossed me,
Meat for my Master she cries, well --

sp.speaker: 3 Em.
sp.l: Once more sir,
We ask your resolutions: peace or war yet?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: War, war, my noble father.

sp.speaker: 1 Em.
sp.l: Thus I fling it:
And fair eyed peace, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have your answer;
Conduct out the Ambassadors, and give them convoys.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Tell your high hearted Masters, they shall not seek us,
Nor cool in the field in expectation of us,
We will ease your men those marches: In their strengths,
And full abilities of mind and courage,
We will find them out, and at their best trim buckle with them

sp.speaker: 3 Em.
sp.l: You will find so hot a Soldiers welcome sir,
Your favour shall not freeze,

sp.speaker: 2 Em.
sp.l: A forward Gentleman,
Pity the wars should bruise such hopes --

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Conduct them --
Now, For this preparation: where is Leontius?
Call him in presently: for I mean in person Gentlemen
Myself , with my old fortune --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Royal sir:
Thus low I beg this honour: fame already
Hath everywhere raised trophies to your glory,
And conquest now grown old, and weak with following
The weary marches, and the bloody shocks
You daily set her in: it is now scarce honour
For you that never knew to fight, but conquer,
To sparkle such poor people: the royal Eagle
When she hath tried her young ones against the Sun,
And found them right; next teacheth them to prey,
How to command on wing, and check below her
Even birds of noble plume; I am your own sir,
You have found my spirit, try it now, and teach it,
To stoop whole kingdoms: leave a little for me;
Let not your glory be so greedy sir,
To eat up all my hopes; you gave me life,
If to that life you add not what is more lasting,
A noble name, for man you have made a shadow:
Bless me this day: bid me go on, and lead,
Bid me go on, no less feared, than Antigonus,
And to my maiden sword, tie fast your fortune;
I know it will fight itself then: dear sir honour me:
Never fair virgin longed so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Rise, and command then,
And be as fortunate as I expect ye:
I love that noble will; your young companions
Bred up and fostered with ye, I hope Demetrius,
You will make soldiers too: they must not leave ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Never till life leave us sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O Leontius,
Here is work for you in hand.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am even right glad sir.
For by my troth, I am now grown old with idleness;
I hear we shall abroad sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, and presently,
But who thinks you commands now?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Who commands sir?
Methinks mine eye should guide me: can there be
(If you yourself will spare him so much honour)
Any found out to lead before your armies,
So full of faith, and fire as brave Demetrius?
King Philips Son, at his years was an old Soldier,
It is time his fortune be a wing, high time sir,
So many idle hours,as here he loiters,
So many ever-living names he loses,
I hope it is he.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is he indeed, and nobly
He shall set forward: draw you all those Garrisons
Upon the frontiers as you pass: to those
Join these in pay at home, our ancient soldiers,
And as you go press all the Provinces.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We shall not need;
Believe this hopeful Gentleman
Can want no swords, nor honest hearts to follow him,
We shall be full, no fear sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You Leontius,
Because you are an old, and faithful servant,
And know the wars, with all his vantages,
Be near to his instructions, lest his youth
Lose valours best companion, staid discretion,
Show where to lead, to lodge, to charge with safety;
In execution not to break, nor scatter,
But with a provident anger, follow nobly:
Not covetous of blood, and death, but honour,
Be ever near his watches; cheer his labours,
And where his hope stands fair, provoke his valour;
Love him,and think it no dishonour (my Demetrius)
To wear this Jewel near thee; he is a tried one,
And one that even in spite of time, that sunk him,
And frosted up his strength, will yet stand by thee.
And with the proudest of thine enemies
Exchange for blood, and bravely: take his counsel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Your grace hath made me young again, and wanton.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She must be known and suddenly; when you have done
Come in and take your leave sir, and some few
Prayers along.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do ye know her?

sp.speaker: Gent.Char.
sp.l: no, believe sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Did you observe her Tymon?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I looked on her,
But what she is --

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must have that found.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know my duty,
You shall be half my father.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: All your Servant:
Come Gentlemen, you are resolved I am sure
To see these wars.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: We dare not leave his fortunes,
Though most assured death hung round about us.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That bargains yet to make;
Be not too hasty, when ye face the Enemy,
Nor too ambitious to get honour instantly,
But charge within your bounds, and keep close bodies,
And you shall see what sport we will make these mad-caps;
You shall have game enough, I warrant ye,
Every man's Cock shall fight.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I must go see sir:
Brave sir, as soon as I have taken leave,
I will meet you in the Park;
Draw the men thither,
Wait you upon Leontius.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We will attend sir.

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: But I beseech your Grace, with speed; the sooner
We are in the field --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You could not please me better.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You never saw the wars yet?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not yet Colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: These foolish Mistresses do so hang about ye,
So whimper, and so hug, I know it Gentlemen,
And so entice ye, now ye are in the bud;
And that sweet tilting war, with eyes and kisses,
The alarms of soft vows, and sighs, and fiddle faddles,
Spoils all our trade: You must forget these knick knacks,
A woman at some time of year, I grant ye
She is necessary; but make no business of her;
How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O sir, as ill as ever;
We shall have wars they say; they are mustering yonder:
Would we were at it once: fie, how it plagues me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Here is one has served now under Captain Cupid,
And cracked a Pike in his youth: you see what is come on it.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: no, my disease will never prove so honourable.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Why sure, thou hast the best pox.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If I have them,
I am sure I got them in the best company;
They are pox of thirty Coats.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Thou hast me wed them finely:
Here is a strange fellow now, and a brave fellow,
If we may say so of a pocky fellow,
(Which I believe we may) this poor Lieutenant;
Whether he have the scratches, or the scabs,
Or what a devil it be, I will say this for him,
There fights no braver soldier under Sun, gentlemen;
Show him an Enemy, his pain is forgot straight;
And where other men, by beds and bathes have ease,
And easy rules of physic, set him in a danger,
A danger, that is a fearful one indeed,
Ye rock him, and he will so play about ye,
Let it be ten to one, he never comes off again;
Ye have his heart: and then he works it bravely,
And thoroughly bravely: not a pang remembered:
I have seen him do such things, belief would shrink at.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is strange he should do all this, and diseased so.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am sure it is true: Lieutenant, canst thou drink well?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Would I were drunk, dog-drunk, I might not feele this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I would take Physic.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: But I would know my disease first.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why? it may be the Cholic: canst thou blow backward?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: There is never a bag-pipe in the kingdom better.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Is it not a pleurisy?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: That has the devil, and death in it: will ye march Gentlemen?
The Prince has taken leave.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How know ye that?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: I saw him leave the Court, dispatch his followers,
And met him after in a bye street: I think
He has some wench, or such a toy, to lick over
Before he go: would I had such another
To draw this foolish pain down.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let us away Gentlemen,
For sure the Prince will stay on us.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We will attend sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Must ye needs go?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Or stay with all dishonour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are there not men enough to fight?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Fie Celia,
This ill becomes the noble love you bear me;
Would you have your love a coward?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No; believe sir,
I would have him fight, but not so far off from me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Wouldst have it thus? or thus?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If that be fighting --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye wanton fool: when I come home again
I will fight with thee,at thine weapon Celia,
And conquer thee too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That you have done already,
You need no other Arms to me, but these sir;
But will you fight yourself sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thus deep in blood wench,
And through the thickest ranks of Pikes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Spur bravely,
Your fiery Courser, beat the troops before ye,
And cram the mouth of death with executions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I would do more than these: But prithee tell me,
Tell me my fair, where gottest thou this male spirit?
I wonder at thy mind.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Were I man then,
You would wonder more.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Sure thou wouldst prove a Soldier,
And some great Leader.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure I should do somewhat;
And the first thing I did, I should grow envious,
Extremely envious of your youth, and honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And fight against me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ten to one, I should do it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou wouldst not hurt me?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: In this mind I am in,
I think I should be hardly brought to strike ye,
Unless it were thus; but in my man's mind --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I should be friends with ye too,
Now I think better.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye are a tall Soldier:
Here, take these, and these;
This gold to furnish ye, and keep this bracelet;
Why do you weep now?
You a masculine spirit?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, I confess I am a fool, a woman:
And ever when I part with you --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: You shall not,
These tears are like prodigious signs, my sweet one,
I shall come back, laden with fame, to honour thee.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I hope you shall:
But then my dear Demetrius,
When you stand Conqueror, and at your mercy
All people bow, and all things wait your sentence;
Say then your eye (surveying all your conquest)
Finds out a beauty, even in sorrow excellent,
A constant face, that in the midst of ruin
With a forced smile, both scorns at fate, and fortune:
Say you find such a one, so nobly fortified.
And in her figure, all the sweets of nature?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee,
No more of this, I cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That shows as far beyond my withered beauty;
And will run mad, to love ye too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Do you fear me,
And do you think, besides this face, this beauty,
This heart, where all my hopes are locked --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare not:
No sure, I think ye honest; wondrous honest.
Pray do not frown, I will swear ye are.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye may choose.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But how long will ye be away?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know you are angry now: pray look upon me:
I will ask no more such questions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The Drums beat,
I can no longer stay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They do but call yet:
How fain you would leave my company.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I would not,
Unless a greater power than love commanded,
Commands my life, mine honour.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But a little.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee farewell, and be not doubtful of me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I would not have ye hurt: and ye are so venturous --
But good sweet Prince preserve yourself, fight nobly,
But do not thrust this body, it is not yours now,
It is mine,it is only mine: do not seek wounds, Sir,
For every drop of blood you bleed --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will Celia,
I will be careful.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My heart, that loves ye dearly.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Prithee no more, we must part:
Hark, they march now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pox on these bawling Drums: I am sure you will kiss me,
But one kiss? what a parting is this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here take me,
And do what thou wilt with me, smother me;
But still remember, if your fooling with me,
Make me forget the trust --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have done: farewell sir,
Never look back, you shall not stay, not a minute.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I must have one farewell more.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, the Drums beat;
I dare not slack your honour; not a hand more,
Only this look; the gods preserve, and save ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What have ye found her out?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: We have hearkened after her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What is that to my desire?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Your grace must give us time,
And a little means.

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: She is sure a stranger,
If she were bred or known here --

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your dull endeavours
Should never be employed. Welcome Menippus.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I have found her sir,
I mean the place she is lodged in; her name is Celia.
And much ado I had to purchase that too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dost think Demetrius loves her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Much I fear it,
But nothing that way yet can win for certain.
I will tell your grace within this hour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A stranger?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Without all doubt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But how should he come to her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: There lies the marrow of the matter hid yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hast thou been with thy wife?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No sir, I am going to her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Go and dispatch, and meet me in the garden,
And get all out ye can.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I will do my best sir.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Blessed be thy wife, thou wert an arrant ass else.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Aye , she is a stirring woman indeed:
There is a brain, brother.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: There is not a handsome wench of any mettle
Within an hundred miles, but her intelligence
Reaches her, and out-reaches her, and brings her
As confidently to Court, as to a sanctuary:
What had his mouldy brains ever arrived at,
Had not she beaten it out of the Flint to fasten him?
They say she keeps an office of Concealments:
There is no young wench, let her be a Saint,
Unless she live in the Centre, but she finds her,
And every way prepares addresses to her:
If my wife would have followed her course Charinthus,
Her lucky course, I had the day before him:
O what might I have been by this time, Brother?
But she (forsooth) when I put these things to her,
These things of honest thrift, groans, O my conscience,
The load upon my conscience, when to make us cuckolds,
They have no more burthen than a brood-goose, brother;
But let us do what we can, though this wench fail us,
Another of a new way will be looked at:
Come, let us abroad, and beat our brains, time may
For all his wisdom, yet give us a day.

body.stage: Drum within, Allarme, Enter Demetrius and Leontius.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will not see them fall thus, give me way sir,
I shall forget you love me else.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will ye lose all?
For me to be forgotten, to be hated,
Nay never to have been a man, is nothing,
So you, and those we have preserved from slaughter
Come safely off.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I have lost myself.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are cozened.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And am most miserable.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: There is no man so, but he that makes himself so.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will go on.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You must not: I shall tell you then,
And tell you true, that man is unfit to govern,
That cannot guide himself: you lead an Army?
That have not so much manly sufferance left ye,
To bear a loss?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Charge but once more Leontius,
My friends and my companions are engaged all.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nay give them lost, I saw them off their horses,
And the enemy master of their Arms; nor could then,
The policy, nor strength of man redeem them.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And shall I know this, and stand fooling?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By my dead fathers soul you stir not, sir,
Or if you do, you make your way through me first.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art a Coward.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: To prevent a Madman.
None but your fathers Son, durst call me so,
'sdeath if he did -- Must I be scandaled by ye,
That hedged in all the helps I had to save ye?
That, where there was a valiant weapon stirring,
Both searched it out, and singled it, unedged it,
For fear it should bite you, am I a coward?
Go, get ye up, and tell them ye are the Kings Son;
Hang all your Ladies favours on your Crest,
And let them fight their shares; spur to destruction,
You cannot miss the way: be bravely desperate,
And your young friends before ye, that lost this battle,
Your honourable friends, that knew no order,
Cry out, Antigonus, the old Antigonus,
The wise and fortunate Antigonus,
The great,the valiant,and the feared Antigenus,
Has sent a desperate son, without discretion
To bury in an hour his age of honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I am ashamed.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It is ten to one, I die with ye:
The coward will not long be after ye;
I scorn to say I saw you fall, sigh for ye,
And tell a whining tale, some ten years after
To boys and girls in an old chimney corner,
Of what a Prince we had, how bravely spirited;
How young and fair he fell: we will all go with ye,
And ye shall see us all, like sacrifices
In our best trim, fill up the mouth of ruin,
Will this faith satisfy your folly? can this show ye,
It is not to die we fear, but to die poorly,
To fall, forgotten, in a multitude?
If you will needs tempt fortune now she has held ye,
Held ye from sinking up.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Pray do not kill me,
These words pierce deeper than the wounds I suffer,
The smarting wounds of loss.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye are too tender;
Fortune has hours of loss, and hours of honour,
And the most valiant feele them both: take comfort,
The next is ours, I have a soul descries it:
The angry bull never goes back for breath,
But when he means to arm his fury double.
Let this day set but not the memory,
And we shall find a time: How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I know not: I am malled: we are bravely beaten,
All our young gallants lost.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art hurt.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I am peppered,
I was in the midst of all: and banged of all hands:
They made an anvil of my head, it rings yet;
Never so threshed: do you call this fame? I have famed it;
I have got immortal fame, but I will no more of it;
I will no such scratching Saint to serve hereafter;
On my conscience I was killed above twenty times,
And yet I know not what a Devil is in it,
I crawled away, and lived again still; I am hurt plaguily,
But now I have nothing near so much pain Colonel,
They have sliced me for that malady.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: All the young men lost?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: I am glad you are here: but they are all in the pound sir,
They will never ride over other men's corn again, I take it,
Such frisking, and such flaunting with their feathers,
And such careering with their mistress favours;
And here must he be pricking out for honour,
And there got he a knock, and down goes pilgarlick,
Commends his soul to his she-saint,and exit.
Another spurs in there, cries make room villains,
I am a Lord, scarce spoken, but with reverence
A rascal takes him over the face, and fells him;
There lies the Lord, the Lord be with him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Now sir,
Do you find this truth?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I would not.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Pox upon it,
They have such tender bodies too; such Cullises,
That one good handsome blow breaks them a pieces.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How stands the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Even cool enough too:
For to say truth he has been shrewdly heated,
The gentleman no doubt will fall to his juleps.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He marches not in the tail of us.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No,plague take him,
He will kiss our tails as soon; he looks upon us,
As if he would say, if ye will turn again, friends,
We will belabour you a little better,
And beat a little more care into your coxcombs.
Now shall we have damnable Ballads out against us,
Most wicked madrigals: and ten to one Colonel,
Sung to such lousy, lamentable tunes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou art merry,
However the game goes: good sir be not troubled,
A better day will draw this back again.
Pray go, and cheer those left, and lead them off,
They are hot, and weary.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will do anything .

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Lieutenant, send one presently away
To the King, and let him know our state: and hark ye,
Be sure the messenger advise his Majesty
To comfort up the Prince: he is full of sadness.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: When shall I get a Surgeon? this hot weather,
Unless I be well peppered, I shall stink Colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Go, I will prepare thee one.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: If ye catch me then,
Fighting again, I will eat hay with a horse.

body.stage: Enter Leucippe (reading)and two Maids at a Table, writing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Have ye written to Merione?

sp.speaker: 1.Ma.
sp.l: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And let her understand the hopes she has
If she come speedily --

sp.speaker: 1.Ma.
sp.l: All these are specified,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And of the chain is sent her,
And the rich stuff to make her show more handsome here?

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.l: All this is done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What have you dispatched there?

sp.speaker: 2 Mai.
sp.l: A letter to the Country maid, if it please ye.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A pretty girl, but peevish, plaguey peevish:
Have ye bought the embroidered gloves, and that purse for her,
And the new Curl?

sp.speaker: 2.Maid.
sp.l: They are ready packed up Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Her maiden-head will yield me; let me see now;
She is not fifteen they say: for her complexion --
Cloe, Cloe, Cloe here, I have her,
Cloe, the Daughter of a Country gentleman;
Her age upon fifteen: now her complexion,
A lovely brown; here it is; eyes black and rolling,
The body neatly built: she strikes a Lute well,
Sings most enticingly: these helps considered,
Her maiden-head will amount to some three hundred,
Or three hundred and; fifty crowns; it will bear it handsomely.
Her father is poor, some little share deducted,
To buy him a hunting Nag; I,it will be pretty:
Who takes care of the Merchants wife?

sp.speaker: 1 Mai.
sp.l: I have wrought her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You know for whom she is?

sp.speaker: 1.Maid.
sp.l: Very well, Madam,
Though very much ado, I had to make her
Apprehend that happiness.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: These kind are subtle:
Did she not cry and blubber when ye urged her.

sp.speaker: 1.Maid.
sp.l: O most extremely, and; swore she would rather perish.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Good signs, very good signs,
Symptoms of easy nature.
Had she the plate?

sp.speaker: 1.Maid.
sp.l: She looked upon it, and left it,
And turned again, and viewed it.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well still.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.l: At length she was content to let it lie there,
Till I called for it, or so,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: She will come?

sp.speaker: 1.Maid.
sp.l: Do you take me
For such a fool, I would part without that promise?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: The Chambers next the park.

sp.speaker: 2.Maid.
sp.l: The Widow Madam,
You bad me look upon.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Hang her, she is musty:
She is no man's meat; beside, she is poor and sluttish:
Where lies old Thisbe now, you are so so long now --

sp.speaker: 2.Ma.
sp.l: Thisbe, Thisbe, This-- agent Thisbe, O I have her,
She lies now in Nicopolis.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Dispatch a packet,
And tell her, her superior here commands her,
The next Month not to fail, but see delivered
Here to our use, some twenty young and handsome,
As also able maids, for the Court service,
As she will answer it: we are out of beauty,
Utterly out, and rub the time away here,
With such blown stuff, I am ashamed to send it.
Who is that? look out,to your business maid,
There is nothing got by idleness: There is a Lady,
Which if I can but buckle with, Altea,
A, A, A, A, Altea young, and married,
And a great lover of her husband, well,
Not to be brought to Court: say ye so? I am sorry,
The Court shall be brought to you then: how now, who is it?

sp.speaker: 1.Maid.
sp.l: An ancient woman, with a maid attending,
A pretty girl, but out of clothes; for a little money,
It seems she would put her to your bringing up, Madam,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Let her come in. Would ye aught with us,good woman?
I pray be short, we are full of business.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I have a tender girl here, if it please your honour.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: That hath a great desire to serve your worship.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: It may be so; I am full of Maids.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: She is young, forsooth --
And for her truth; and as they say her bearing.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ye say well: come ye hither maid, let me feel your pulse,
It is somewhat weak, but nature will grow stronger,
Let me see your leg, she treads but low in the pasterns.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: A cork heel Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: We know what will do it,
Without your aim good woman: what do you pitch her at?
She is but a slight toy -- cannot hold out long.

sp.speaker: VVom.
sp.l: Even what yon think is meet.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Give her ten Crowns, we are full of business,
She is a poor woman, let her take a Cheese home:
Enter the wench in the office.

sp.speaker: 2.Maid.
sp.l: What is your name, sister?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.l: Phebe forsooth.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A pretty name; it will do well:
Go in,and let the other maid instruct ye Phebe;
Let my old velvet skirt be made fit for her,
I will put her into action for a waistcoat,
And when I have rigged her up once, this small Pinnace
Shall sail for gold, and good store too: who is there?
Lord, shall we never have any ease in this world?
Still troubled? still molested? what would you have?
I cannot furnish ye faster than I am able
If ye were my husband a thousand times, I cannot do it;
At least a dozen posts are gone this morning
For several parts of the Kingdom: I can do no more
But pay them, and instruct them.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Prithee, good sweet heart,
I come not to disturb thee, nor discourage thee,
I know thou labourest truly: hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ha?
What do you make so dainty on it? look there,
I am an Ass, I can do nothing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Celia? Aye , this is she; a stranger born.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What would you give for more now?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Prithee, my best Leucippe, there is much hangs on it
Lodged at the end of Marses street? that is true too;
At the sack of such a Town, by such a Soldier
Preserved a prisoner: and by Prince Demetrius
Bought from that man again, maintained, and favoured:
How came you by this knowledge?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Poor weak man,
I have a thousand eyes, when thou art sleeping,
Abroad, and full of business.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You never tried her?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No, she is beyond my level; so hedged in
By the Princes infinite love, and favour to her --

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She is a handsome wench.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A delicate, and knows it;
And out of that proof arms herself.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Come in then;
I have a great design from the King to you,
And you must work like wax now.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: On this Lady?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: On this, and all your wits call home.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I have done.
Toys in my time of some note; old as I am,
I think my brains will work without barm,
Take up the Books.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: As we go in, I will tell ye.

body.stage: Enter Antigonus, Tymon, Lords, and a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No face of sorrow for this loss? it will choake him,
Nor no man miss a friend, I know his nature
So deep impressed with grief, for what he has suffered,
That the least adding to it,adds to his ruin;
His loss is not so infinite, I hope Soldier.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Faith neither great, nor out of discretion,
The young men out of heat.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I guess the manner.

sp.speaker: Lord Men.
sp.l: The Prince if it like your Grace --

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are welcome home sir;
Come, no more sorrow, I have heard your fortune,
And I myself have tried the like: clear up man,
I will not have ye take it thus; if I doubted.
Your fear had lost; and that you had turned your back to them,
Basely besought their mercies --

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No,no, by this hand sir,
We fought like honest and tall men.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: I know it Leontius, or if I thought
Neglect of rule, having his council with ye,
Or too vainglorious appetite of fame,
Your men forgot, and scattered.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: None of these sir,
He showed himself a noble gentleman,
Every way apt to rule.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These being granted;
Why should you think you have done an act so heinous,
That naught but discontent dwells round about ye?
I have lost a Battle.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Aye , and fought it hard too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With as much means as man --

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Or devil could urge it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Twenty to one of our side now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Turn Tables,
Beaten like dogs again, like Owls, you take it
To heart for flying but a mile before them,
And to say truth,it was no flight neither sir,
It was but a walk, a handsome walk,
I have tumbled with this old body, beaten like a stock-fish,
And stuck with arrows, like an arming Quiver,
Blooded and banged, almost a day before them,
And glad I have got off then. Here is a mad shaver,
He fights his share I am sure, whenever he comes to it;
Yet I have seen him trip it tithely too,
And cry the devil take the hindmost ever.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I learned it of my betters.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Budge at this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Has fortune but one face?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: In her best vizard,
Methinks she looks but lousily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Chance, though she faint now,
And sink below our expectations,
Is there no hope left strong enough to boy her?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It is not this day, I fled before the enemy,
And lost my people, left mine honour murdered,
My maiden honour, never to be ransomed,
( Which to a noble soul is too too sensible)
Afflicts me with this sadness; most of these,
Time may turn straight again, experience perfect,
And new swords, cut new ways to nobler fortunes.
O I have lost --

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: As you are mine forget it:
I do not think it loss.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.l: O sir, forgive me,
I have lost my friends, those worthy souls bred with me,
I have lost myself, they were the pieces of me;
I have lost all Arts, my Schools are taken from me,
Honour and Arms, no emulation left me:
I lived to see these men lost, looked upon it;
These men that twined their loves to mine, their vertues,
O shame of shames, I saw, and could not save them,
This carries sulphur in it, this burns and boils me,
And like a fatal Tomb bestrides my memory.

sp.speaker: Antig.
sp.l: This was hard fortune, but if alive, and taken,
They shall be ransomed, let it be at Millions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: They are dead, they are dead.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: When would he weep for me thus?
I may be dead,and powdered.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good Prince,grieve not:
WE&Htp; are not certain of their deaths: the enemy,
Though he be hot, and keen,
Yet holds good Quarter.
What noise is this?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: He does not follow us?
Give me a steeple top.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: They live, they live sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold up your manly face;
They live, they are here,Son.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: These are the men.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: They are, and live to honour ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How scaped ye noble friends? methought I saw ye
Even in the jaws of death.

sp.speaker: 2.Gent.
sp.l: Thanks to our folly,
That spurred us on; we were indeed hedged round in it,
And even beyond the hand of succour beaten,
Unhorsed, disarmed: and what we looked for then sir,
Let such poor weary souls that hear the Bell knoll,
And see the grave a-digging , tell.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: For heaven sake
Delude mine eyes no longer: how came ye off?

sp.speaker: 1.Gent.
sp.l: Against all expectation:the brave Seleucus,
I think this day enamoured on your virtue,
When , through the Troops, he saw ye shoot like lightning;
And at your manly courage all took fire,
And after that ,the misery we fell too,
The never-certain fate of war considering,
As we stood all before him, fortunes ruins,
Nothing but death expecting, a short time
He made a stand upon our youths and fortunes,
Then with an eye of mercy informed his judgment,
How yet unripe we were, unblown, unhardened,
Unfitted for such fatal ends; he cried out to us,
Go Gentlemen, commend me to your Master,
To the most high,and hopeful prince Demetrius,
Tell him the valour that he showed against me
This day, the virgin valour, and true fire
Deserves, even from an Enemy, this courtesy;
Your lives and Arms freely I will give them: thank him,
And thus we are returned Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Faith it was well done;
It was bravely done;was it not a noble part Sir?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Had I been there up had I gone, I am sure on it;
These noble tricks, I never durst trust them yet.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let me not live, if it were not a famed honesty,
It takes me such a tickling way: now would I wish heaven,
But even the happiness, even that poor blessing
For all the sharp afflictions thou hast sent me,
But even in the head of the field to take Seleucus.
I should do something memorable: fie,sad still.

sp.speaker: 1.Gent.
sp.l: Do you grieve we are come off?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Unransomed,was it?

sp.speaker: 2.Gent.
sp.l: It was sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: And with such a fame to me?
Said ye not so?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ye have heard it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Leontius O
Better I had lost them all: myself had perished,
And all my fathers hopes,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Mercy upon ye,
What ail ye Sir? 'sdeath,do not make fools of us ,
Neither go to Church, nor tarry at home,
That is a fine Hornpipe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What is now your grief Demetrius?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Did he not beat us twice?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He beat a pudding;
Beat us but once.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Has beat me twice, and beat me to a coward,
Beat me to nothing.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Is not the devil in him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I pray it be no worse.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Twice conquered me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bear witness all the world, I am a dunce here.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: With valour first he struck me, then with honour;
That struck Leontius, that struck, dost thou not feele it?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Whereabouts was it? for I remember nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: All these gentlemen
That were his prisoners --

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Yes, he set them free sir,
With Arms and honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: There, there, now thou hast it;
At mine own weapon, Courtesy, he has beaten me,
At that I was held a Master in, he has cowed me,
Hotter than all the dint of the fight he has charged me:
Am I not now a wretched fellow? think on it;
And when thou hast examined all ways honourable,
And findest no door left open to requite this,
Conclude I am a wretch,and was twice beaten.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have observed your way,and understand it,
And equal love it as Demetrius;
My noble child thou shalt not fall in virtue,
I and my power will sink first: you Leontius,
Wait for a new Commission, ye shall out again,
And instantly: you shall not lodge this night here,
Not see a friend, nor take a blessing with ye,
Before ye be in the field : the enemy is up still,
And still in full design: Charge him again, Son,
And either bring home that again thou hast lost there,
Or leave thy body by him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye raise me,
And now I dare look up again, Leontius.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Aye, aye , sir, I am thinking who we shall take of them,
To make all straight; and who we shall give to the devil.
What sayst thou now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I say nothing.
Lord what ail, I, that I have no mind to fight now?
I find my constitution mightily altered
Since I came home: I hate all noises too,
Especially the noise of Drums; I am now as well
As any living man; why not as valiant?
To fight now, is a kind of vomit to me,
It goes against my stomach.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Good sir, presently;
You cannot do your Son, so fair a favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is my intent: I will see ye march away too;
Come, get your men together presently, Leontius,
And press where please you, as you march.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We go sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wait you on me,I will bring ye to your command,
And then to fortune give you up.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Ye love me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Go, get the drums, beat round, Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Hark ye, sir,
I have a foolish business they call marriage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: After the wars are done.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: The party stays sir,
I have given the Priest his money too: all my friends sir,
My father, and my mother.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Will you go forward?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: She brings a pretty matter with her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Half a dozen Bastards.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Some forty sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A goodly competency.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I mean sir, pounds a year; I will dispatch the matter,
It is but a night or two; I will overtake ye sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The two old legions, yes: where lies the horse-quarter?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And if it be a boy, I will even make bold sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Away with your whore,
A plague on your whore, you damned rogue,
Now ye are cured and well; must ye be clicketing?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I have broke my mind to my Ancient, in my absence,
He is a sufficient gentleman.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Get forward.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Only receive her portion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Get ye forward;
Else I will bang ye forward.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Strange sir,
A Gentleman and an officer cannot have the liberty
To do the office of a man.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Shame light on thee,
How came this whore into thy head?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: This whore sir?
It is strange,a poor whore.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Do not answer me:
Troop, Troop away; do not name this whore again,
Or think there is a whore.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: That is very hard sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For if thou dost,look to it, I will have thee gelded,
I will walk ye out before me: not a word more.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ye are the Mistress of the house ye say,
Where this young Lady lies.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: For want of a better.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You may be good enough for such a purpose:
When was the Prince with her? answer me directly.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: Not since he went a-warring .

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: Very well then:
What carnal copulation are you privy too
Between these two? be not afraid, we are women,
And may talk thus amongst ourselves , no harm in it.

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: No sure,there is no harm in it, I conceive that;
But truly, that I ever knew the gentlewoman
Otherwise given, than a hopeful gentlewoman --

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: You will grant me the Prince loves her?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: There I am with ye.
And the gods bless her, promises her mightily.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Stay there a while. And gives her gifts?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Extremely;
And truly makes a very Saint of her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I should think now,
(Good woman let me have your judgment with me,
I see it is none of the worst: Come sit down by me)
That these two cannot love so tenderly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Being so young as they are too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You say well --
But that methinks some further promises --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Yes, yes,
I have heard the Prince swear he would marry her.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: Very well still: they do not use to fall out?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: The tenderest Chickens to one another,
They cannot live an hour asunder.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I have done then;
And be you gone; you know your charge, and do it.
You know whose will it is; if you transgress it --
That is, if any have access, or see her,
Before the Kings will be fulfilled --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Not the Prince, Madam?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You will be hanged if you it, that I will assure ye.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: But nevertheless, I will make bold to obey ye.

sp.speaker: Leuc.
sp.l: Away, and to your business then.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It is done,Madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Menippus Thou hast taken wondrous pains; but yet
You understand not of what blood, and; country.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I laboured that, but cannot come to know it.
A Greek I am sure she is, she speaks this language.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is she so excellent handsome?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Most enticing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sold for a prisoner?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Yes sir,
Some poor creature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And he loves tenderly?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: They say extremely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is well prevented then: yes, I perceived it:
When he took leave now, he made a hundred stops,
Desired an hour, but half an hour, a minute,
Which I with anger crossed; I knew his business,
I knew it was she he hunted on; this journey, man,
I beat out suddenly for her cause intended,
And would not give him time to breath. When comes she?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: This morning sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lodge her to all delight then:
For I would have her tried to the test: I know,
She must be some cracked coin, not fit his traffic,
Which when we have found, the shame will make him leave her,
Or we shall work a nearer way: I will bury him,
And with him all the hopes I have cast upon him,
Ere he shall dig his own grave in that woman:
You know which way to bring her: I will stand close there,
To view her as she passes: and do you hear Menippus,
Observe her with all sweetness: humour her,
It will make her lie more careless to our purposes.
Away, and take what helps you please.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I am gone sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Governess, from whom was this Gown sent me?
Prithee be serious true; I will not wear it else:
It is a handsome one.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: As though you know not?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No faith:
But I believe, for certain too, yet I wonder,
Because it was his caution, this poor way,
Still to preserve me from the curious searchings
Of greedy eyes.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You have it: does it please you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is very rich, methinks too, prithee tell me?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: From one that likes you well, never look coy, Lady;
These are no gifts, to be put off with poutings.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Poutings, and gifts? is it from any stranger?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are so curious, that there is no talk to ye.
What if it be I pray ye?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Unpin good Governess,
Quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Quick, good Governess:
Fie on it, how beastly it becomes me? poorly?
A trick put in upon me? well said Governess:
I vow I would not wear it -- out,it smells musty.
Are these your tricks? now I begin to smell it
Abominable musty; will ye help me?
The Prince will come again --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are not mad sure?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: As I live I will cut it off: a pox upon it;
For sure it was made for that use; do you bring me Liveries?
Stales to catch Kites? dost thou laugh too, thou base woman?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I cannot choose, if I should be hanged.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Abuse me,
And then laugh at me too?

sp.speaker: Gover.
sp.l: I do not abuse ye:
Is it abuse, to give him drink that is thirsty?
You want clothes; is it such a heinous sin I beseech ye,
To see you stored?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is no greater wickedness
Than this way.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What way?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I shall curse thee fearefully,
If thou provokest me further: and take heed, woman;
My curses never miss.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Curse him that sent it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Tell but his name --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You dare not curse him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare not?
By this fair light --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are so full of passion --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dare not be good? be honest? dare not curse him?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I think you dare not: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Speak him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Up with your valour then, up with it bravely,
And take your full charge.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If I do not, hang me;
Tell but his name.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It was Prince Demetrius sent it:
Now, now, give fire, kill him in the eye now Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is he come home?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It seems so; but your curse now.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: You do not lie, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You dare not curse him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Prithee do not abuse me: is he come home indeed?
For I would now with all my heart believe thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Nay, you may choose: alas, I deal for strangers,
That send ye scurvy musty Gowns, stale Liveries:
I have my tricks.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is a good gown, a handsome one;
I did but jest; where is he?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He that sent it --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How? he that sent it? is it come to that again?
Thou canst not be so foolish: prithee speak out,
I may mistake thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I said he that sent it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Curse on my life: why dost thou vex me thus?
I know thou meanest Demetrius, dost thou not?
I charge thee speak truth: if it be any other,
Thou knowest the charge he gave thee, and the justice
His anger will inflict, if ever he know this,
As know he shall, he shall, thou spiteful woman,
Thou beastly woman; and thou shalt know too late too,
And feele too sensible, I am no ward,
No sale stuff for your money Merchants that sent it?
Who dare send me, or how durst thou, thou --

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What you please:
For this is ever the reward of service.
The Prince shall bring the next himself.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is strange
That you should deal so peevishly: beshrew ye,
You have put me in a heat.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am sure ye have killed me:
I never received such language: I can but wait upon ye,
And be your drudge; keep a poor life to serve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You know my nature is too easy, Governess,
And you know now, I am sorry too: how does he?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: O God, my head.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Prithee be well, and tell me,
Did he speak of me, since he came? nay, see now,
If thou wilt leave this tyranny? good sweet governess,
Did he but name his Celia? look upon me,
Upon my faith I meant no harm: here, take this,
And buy thyself some trifles: did he good wench?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He loves ye but too dearly.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That is my good Governess.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: There is more clothes making for ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: More clothes?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: More:
Richer and braver; I can tell ye that news;
And twenty glorious things.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To what use sirra?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ye are too good for our house now: we poor wretches
Shall lose the comfort of ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No, I hope not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Forever lose ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Lose me? wherefore?
I hear of no such thing.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: It is sure it must be so:
You must shine now at Court: such preparation,
Such hurry, and such hanging rooms --

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To the Court wench?
Was it to the Court thou saidst?

sp.speaker: Gox.
sp.l: You will find it so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Stay, stay, this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I say it must be:
I hope to find ye still the same good Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To the Court? this stumbles me: art sure for me, wench,
This preparation is?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: She is perilous crafty:
I fear too honest for us all too. Am I sure I live?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To the Court? this cannot down: what should I do there?
Why should he on a sudden change his mind thus,
And not make me acquainted? sure he loves me;
His vow was made against it, and mine with him:
At least while this King lived: he will come hither,
And see me ere I go?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Would some wise woman
Had her in working: that I think he will not,
Because he means with all joy there to meet ye.
Ye shall hear more within this hour?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: A Courtier?
What may that meaning be? sure he will see me
If he be come, he must: Hark ye good Governess,
What age is the King of?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He is an old man, and full of business.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I fear too full indeed: what Ladies are there?
I would be loath to want good company.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Delicate young Ladies, as you would desire;
And when you are acquainted, the best company.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is very well: prithee go in, let us talk more.
For though I fear a trick, I will bravely try it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I see he must be cunning,
Knocks this Doe down.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You shall not have your will,sirra, are ye running?
Have ye gotten a toy in your heels? Is this a season,
When honour pricks ye on, to prick your ears up,
After your whore, your Hobby-horse?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Why look ye now:
What a strange man are you? would you have a man fight
At all hours all alike.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Do but fight something;
But half a blow, and put thy stomach to it:
Turn but thy face, and do but make mouths at them .

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And have my teeth knocked out; I thank ye heartily,
Ye are my dear friend.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What a devil ails thee?
Dost long to be hanged?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I make no suit for it:
But rather than I would live thus out of charity,
Continually in brawling --

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Art thou not he?
I may be cozened --

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: I shall be discovered.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That in the midst of thy most hellish pains,
When thou wert crawling sick, didst aim at wonders,
When thou wert mad with pain?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Ye have found the cause out;
I had never been mad to fight else: I confess sir,
The daily torture of my side that vexed me,
Made me as daily careless what became of me,
Till a kind sword there wounded me, and eased me;
It was nothing in my valour fought; I am well now,
And take some pleasure in my life, methinks now,
It shows as mad a thing to me to see you scuffle,
And kill one another foolishly for honour,
As it was to you, to see me play the coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And wilt thou never fight more?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: In the mind I am in,

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Nor never be sick again?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I hope I shall not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Prithee be sick again; prithee,I beseech thee,
Be just so sick again.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I will just be hanged first.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: If all the Arts that are can make a Cholic,
Therefore look to it: or if imposthumes, mark me,
As big as footballs --

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Deliver me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Or stones of ten pound weight in the kidneys,
Through ease and ugly diets may be gathered;
I will feed ye up myself sir, I will prepare ye,
You cannot fight, unless the devil tear ye,
You shall not want provocations, I will scratch ye,
I will have thee have the tooth-ach, and the head-ach.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Colonel, I will do anything.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No, no, nothing --
Then will I have thee blown with a pair of Smiths bellows,
Because ye shall be sure to have a round gale with ye,
Aqua fortis Filled full of oil,on devil, and
And let these work, these may provoke.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Colonel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A coward in full blood; prithee be plain with me,
Will roasting do thee any good?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Nor basting neither, sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Marry that goes hard.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Where are you Colonel?
The Prince expects ye sir; has hedged the enemy
Within a straight, where all the hopes and valours
Of all men living cannot force a passage,
He has them now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I knew all this before sir,
I chalked him out his way: but do you see that thing there?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Nay good sweet Colonel, I will fight a little.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That thing?

sp.speaker: 1.Gent.
sp.l: What thing? I see the brave Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Rogue, what a name hast thou lost?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You may help it?
Yet you may help it: I will do ye any courtesy:
I know you love a wench well.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look upon him;
Do you look too.

sp.speaker: 2.Gent.
sp.l: What should I look on?
I come to tell ye, the Prince stays your direction,
We have them now in the Coop, sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let them rest there,
And chew upon their miseries: but look first --

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I cannot fight for all this.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Look on this fellow.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I know him;it is the valiant brave Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Canst thou hear this, and play the rogue? steal off quickly,
Behind me quickly, neatly do it,
And rush into the thickest of the enemy,
And if thou killest but two.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: You may excuse me,
It is not my fault: I dare not fight.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Be ruled yet
I will beat thee on; go wink and fight: a plague upon your sheeps heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: What is all this matter?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Nay I cannot show ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Here is twenty pound, go but smell to them.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Alas sir,
I have taken such a cold I can smell nothing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I can smell a rascal, a rank rascal:
Fie, how he stinks,stinks like a tired Jade.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why, that sir, do not you smell him?

sp.speaker: 2.Gent.
sp.l: Smell him?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I must endure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Stinks like a dead dog, Carrion --
There is no such damnable smell under heaven,
As the faint sweat of a Coward: will ye fight yet?

sp.speaker: Lie.
sp.l: Nay, now I defy ye; ye have spoke the worst ye can
Of me, and if every man should take what you say
To the heart. --

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: God a mercy,
God a mercy with all my heart; here I forgive thee;
And fight, or fight not,do but go along with us,
And keep my dog.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I love a good dog naturally.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: What is all this stir,Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieut.
sp.l: Nothing Sir,
But a slight matter of argument.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pox take thee.
Sure I shall love this rogue, he is so pretty a Coward,
Come gentlemen, let us up now, and if fortune
Dare play the slut again, I will never more Saint her,
Come play fellow, come,prithee come up; come chicken,
I have a way shall fit yet: A tame knave.
Come, look upon us.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I will tell ye who does best boys.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I saw her coming out,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who waits upon her?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Tymon, Charinthus and some other gentlemen,
By me appointed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is your wife?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She is ready
To entertain her here sir; and some Ladies
Fit for her lodgings.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How shows she in her trim now?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: O most divinely sweet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee speak softly.
How does she take her coming?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She bears it bravely;
But what she thinks -- For heaven sake sir preserve me --
If the Prince chance to find this.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace ye old fool;
She thinks to meet him here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: That is all the Project.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Was she hard to bring?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: No, she believed it quickly,
And quickly made herself fit, the Gown a little,
And those new things she has not been acquainted with,
At least in this place, where she lived a prisoner,
Troubled and stirred her mind, But believe me sir,
She has worn as good, they sit so apted to her;
And she is so great a Mistress of disposure:
Here they come now: but take a full view of her.

body.stage: Enter Celia, Tymon, Charinthus, and Gent.

sp.l: How cheerfully she looks? how she salutes all?
And how she views the place? she is very young sure:
That was an admirable smile, a catching one,
The very twang of Cupids bow sung to it:
She has two-edged eyes, they kill on both sides.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She makes a stand, as though she would speak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be still then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen, trouble your selves no further,
I had thought sure to have met a noble friend here.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Ye may meet many Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Such as you are
I covet few or none,sir.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Will you walk this way,
And take the sweets of the garden? cool and close, Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Methinks this open air is far better, tend ye that way.
Pray where is the woman came along?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What woman?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The woman of the house I lay at.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Woman?
Here was none came along sure.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Sure I am catched then:
Pray where is the Prince?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: He will not be long from ye,
We are his humble servants.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I could laugh now,
To see how finely I am cozened: yet I fear not,
For sure I know a way to scape all dangers.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Madam,your lodgings lie this way.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: My Lodgings?
For heaven sake sir, what office do I bear here?

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: The great commander of all hearts

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You have hit it.
I thank your sweet-heart for it. Who are these now?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Ladies that come to serve ye.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well considered,
Are you my servants?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Servants to your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I dare believe ye, but I dare not trust ye:
Catched with a trick? well, I must bear it patiently:
Methinks this Court is a neat place: all the people
Of such refined a size --

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: This is no poor rogue.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Were it a Paradise to please your fancy,
And entertain the sweetness you bring with ye;

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Take breath;
You are fat, and many words may melt ye,
This is three Bawds beaten into one; bless me heaven,
What shall become of me? I am in the pitfall:
O my conscience, this is the old viper, and all these little ones
Creep every night into her belly; do you hear plump servant
And you my little sucking Ladies, you must teach me,
For I know you are excellent at carriage,
How to behave myself, for I am rude yet:
But you say the Prince will come?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Will fly to see you.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For look you if a great man, say the King now
Should come and visit me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: She names ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace fool.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And offer me a kindness, such a kindness.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Aye , such a kindness.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: True Lady such a kindness,
What shall that kindness be now?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A witty Lady,
Learn little ones, learn.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Say it be all his favour.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: And a sweet saying it is.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And I grow peevish?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You must not be neglectful.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: There is the matter,
There is the main doctrine now, and I may miss it.
Or a kind handsome Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: You say well.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: They will count us basely bred.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Not freely nurtured.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I will take thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: It is an excellent woman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I find a notable volume here, a learned one;
Which way? for I would fain be in my chamber;
In truth sweet Ladies, I grow weary; fie,
How hot the air beats on me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: This way Madam?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now by mine honour, I grow wondrous faint too.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Your fans sweet Gentlewomen, your fans.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Since I am fooled,
I will make myself some sport, though I pay dear for it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: You see now what a manner of woman she is sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou art an ass.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Is this a fit love for the Prince?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A coxcomb:
Now by my crown a dainty wench, a sharpe wench,
And a matchless spirit: how she Jeered them?
How carelessly she scoffed them? use her nobly;
I would I had not seen her: wait anon,
And then you shall have more to trade upon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: We must keep a round, and a strong watch tonight ,
The Prince will not charge the Enemy till the morning:
But for the trick I told ye for this rascal.
This rogue, that health and strong heart makes a coward.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Aye , if it take.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Never fear it, the Prince has it,
And if he let it fall, I must not know it;
He will suspect me presently: but you two
May help the plough.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: That he is sick again.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Extremely sick: his disease grown incurable,
Never yet found, nor touched at.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Well,we have it
And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Prince has been upon him,
What a flatten face he has now? it takes believe it;
How like an ass he looks?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I feele no great pain,
At least, I think I do not; yet I feele sensibly
I grow extremely faint: how cold I sweat now?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So, so, so.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: And now it is even too true, I feele a pricking,
A pricking, a strange pricking: how it tingles?
And as it were a stitch too: the Prince told me,
And Everyone cried out I was a dead man;
I had thought I had been as well --

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Upon him now boys,
And do it most demurely.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I thank ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Life, how looks this man?
How dost thou good Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: I ever told ye
This man was never cured, I see it too plain now;
How do you feele yourself? you look not perfect,
How dull his eye hangs?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: That may be discontent.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Believe me friend, I would not suffer now
The tithe of those pains this man feels; mark his forehead
What a cloud of cold dew hangs upon it?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I have it,
Again I have it; how it grows upon me?
A miserable man I am.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, A miserable man thou shalt be,
This is the tamest trout I ever tickled.

sp.speaker: 1 Phis.
sp.l: This way he went.

sp.speaker: 2 Phis.
sp.l: Pray heaven we find him living,
He is a brave fellow, it is pity he should perish thus.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: A strong hearted man, and; of a notable sufferance.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O, O.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: How now? how is it man?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O Gentlemen,
Never so full of pain.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Did I not tell ye?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Never so full of pain Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: He is here;
How do you sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: Be of good comfort Soldier,
The Prince has sent us to you.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Do you think I may live?

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: He alters hourly,strangely.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: Yes, you may live:but --

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Finely butted Doctor.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Do not discourage him.

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: He must be told truth,
It is now too late to trifle.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Here the Prince comes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How now Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Bewailing sir, a Soldier,
And one I think, your Grace will grieve to part with,
But every living thing --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: It is true, must perish,
Our lives are but our marches to our graves,
How dost thou now Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Faith it is true sir,
We are but spans,and candles ends.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He is finely mortified.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Thou art heart whole yet; I see he alters strangely,
And that a pace too; I saw it this morning in him,
When he poor man, I dare swear --

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: No believe it sir,
I never felt it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here is lies the pain now: how he is swelled?

sp.speaker: 1 Phi.
sp.l: The Imposthume
Fed with a new malignant humour now,
Will grow to such a bigness, it is incredible,
The compass of a bushel will not hold it,
And with such a hell of torture it will rise too. --

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Can you endure me touch it?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: O , I beseech you sir:
I feele you sensibly ere you come near me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: He is finely wrought, he must be cut, no cure else,
And suddenly, you see how fast he blows out.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Good Master Doctor, let me be beholding to you,
I feele I cannot last.

sp.speaker: 2 Phi.
sp.l: For what Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: But even for half a dozen Cans of good wine,
That I may drink my will out: I faint hideously.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Fetch him some wine; and since he must go gentlemen
Why let him take his journey merrily.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: That is even the nearest way.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I could laugh dead now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Here, off with that.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: These two I give your Grace,
A poor remembrance of a dying man sir,
And I beseech you wear them out.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will Soldier,
These are fine legacies.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: Among the Gentlemen,
Even all I have left; I am a poor man, naked,
Yet something for remembrance: four a piece Gentlemen,
And so my body where you please.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It will work.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I make your Grace my executor, and I beseech ye
See my poor will fulfilled: sure I shall walk else.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: As full as they can be filled, here is my hand Soldier.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: The wine will tickle him.

sp.speaker: Lieu.
sp.l: I would hear a drum beat,
But to see how I could endure it.
